awd_titl_txt: RCN: Advancing Research and Education Through a National Network of Campus Research Computing Infrastructures - The CaRC Consortium
awd_abstract_narration:
As the role of computing in scientific discovery continues to increase, campuses across the country are challenged with the task of providing effective facilitation for computing capabilities so that researchers can harness these capabilities in their investigations. Such facilitation requires novel organizational approaches to the way that both human and physical resources that constitute campus research computing capabilities are composed, structured, and operated. The mission of the Campus Research Computing (CaRC) Infrastructures Consortium is to provide a national forum for the exchange and dissemination of best practices, expertise and technologies, enabling the advancement of campus-based research computing activities.  By bringing together a wide range of campuses and community stakeholders, the CaRC Consortium provides a novel, yet complementary, element of an evolving and expanding national cyberinfrastructure ecosystem. 

Governed by a council according to the consortium bylaws, the CaRC Consortium acts as unique force in advancing the impact of computing on the productivity of faculty and students.  As an organization that is driven by the campus perspective of research computing, the CaRC offers several key outcomes at a national scale including the sharing of knowledge, best practices, software and hardware technologies, expertise, workforce development, and professional development.  This fills a void within the national research computing fabric; as more campuses recognize the value of investments in research computing capacity and also in facilitators and like-functioning positions, many of these campuses and their individual staff members are isolated in a new field of practice without the necessary supporting infrastructure from a practitioner community.

por.por_cntn:
As a result of this funded project, the Research Coordination Network known as the Campus Research Computing Consortium (CaRCC) has emerged and evolved into a sustained organization of dedicated professionals developing, advocating for, and advancing campus research computing and data capabilities and associated professions. CaRCC's now-expanded "research computing and data" (RCD+) focus reflects community evolution beyond the narrower "research computing" moniker from prior significant investment in high-performance computing, specifically. The RCD+ focus has been applied to involve people, scholarship, and resources supporting the IT specific to research and scholarship leveraging compute, data, networking, and software, broadly defined, as well as the professionals who execute and support these efforts (aligning inclusively beyond NSF definitions of "cyberinfrastructure"). Like an ongoing conference, the CaRCC People Network supports community-building that engages a variety of RCD+ professionals in discussion "tracks" representing the essential expertise of researcher-facing, data-facing, software-facing, systems-facing, and strategy- and policy-facing professional roles, as well as a group for emerging RCD+ service-providers. Each track is coordinated by a group of volunteers and via CaRCC-coordinated, community-contributed infrastructure for email/chat communication (with more than 1300 unique members), web content, community documents, calendaring, and monthly virtual meetings open to the entire RCD+ community, most of which have recordings available via YouTube. Tracks are either represented by or are executed in coordination with other communities across the RCD+ ecosystem (e.g. US Research Software Engineers for Software-Facing, EDUCAUSE's Research Computing and Data group, the Coalition for Advanced Scientific Computation, Campus Champions, etc.).

Leveraging input from People Network community and the same common infrastructure developed as part of the project, CaRCC has supported and continues to support a number of working groups addressing key concerns across the RCD+ professional community and the organizations they work for. These have included working groups and workshops to: 

  • connect and define the broader of RCD+ organizations and communities

  • define common RCD+ stakeholders and shared value propositions for the academic research community at a time of accelerating change

  • characterize and professionalize RCD+ roles

  • support RCD+ workforce and career development

  • evaluate and recommend RCD+ strategies for campuses within EPSCOR states, and

  • characterize and enhance the engagement and representation of RCD+ participants across these efforts and the CaRCC People Network.

 

Key CaRCC-supported outcomes to the community from these activities include:

  • an RCD+ job category framework and Capabilities Assessment Model (both of which have been adopted in some form by a number of campuses)

  • documented Value Proposition principles, characterization of the national RCD+ ecosystem

  • surveys and reports capturing the RCD+ workforce

  • a charter for CaRCC as an organization

  • dozens of presentations and peer-reviewed papers capturing the results of the above activities

  • published annual reports, and

  • the CaRCC website where these are additionally listed and promoted. 

Given the organizational evolution of CaRCC in leveraging significant volunteer contributions, key (additional) funding for specific working group activities and products, an external Advisory Group (as of early 2022), and collaborations with other RCD+ community-building organizations, these outcomes and activities will be sustained and expanded beyond the scope of the project.
